awd_titl_txt: US/Morocco Workshop on Sensors and Wireless Networks for Smart Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports US researchers' participation in a joint US/Moroccan workshop on research frontiers in the field of devices and wireless networks for smart cities. The workshop will bring together experts in a collaborative framework to discuss current challenges and converge on needed research directions in sensors and wireless technologies that will enable smart cities. In the smart cities area, most of the advances have been in deployment of technologies and mostly in advanced countries. Significant research activities are still lagging in this field. Morocco is very interested in applying smart city concepts in the country, and is indeed building a new city envisioned to include smart electric power grid and other smart city infrastructure. There is therefore a real and timely need for advancing smart city research globally, and for helping to establish strong smart city research in Morocco. Through this workshop, US researchers in the field of sensors, wireless networks, and computing for smart cities will be able to share experience and research ideas with their Moroccan counterparts. The researchers will identify complementary collaborative research projects, as well as ideas for enhancing education and training. Successful implementation of the workshop recommendations can provide an important example for other developing nations for planning of smart city applications. The research challenges addressed by this workshop are global in nature and there is great potential for broader impacts that address energy issues and grand challenges and national needs in the arena of smart grid, smart transportation networks, smart building, human modeling and efficient development across a range of scales from individual space planning to urban and regional planning and development. Gathering interdisciplinary experts from around the world to address these issues presents broader impact opportunities. The broader impacts and implications of this project stem from the fact that Morocco is a developing country and there is opportunity to develop new cities from the ground up whereas US technologies can be broadly applied and marketed.

Recent technical achievements in sensors and controls integrated with active systems can allow for the ability to control the built environment and tailor it to societal preferences, while still maintaining optimal operation, energy conservation, sustainability and resiliency. With the use of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN), cities can move toward the concept of smart cities. A smart city behaves as a cyber-physical system (CPS) that deeply integrates sensing, computation, communication, and control. However, implementation of smart CPSs that are reliable and autonomous face many challenges, as future CPSs are composed of heterogeneous systems. The workshop will address research challenges related to the development and implementation of smart cities and (1) produce a research agenda in sensors and wireless networks that addresses issues needed to effectively implement smart cities; (2) foster collaboration between US and Moroccan scientists and engineers; (3) induce educational progress to match new technology developments through (a) Participation of US and Moroccan faculty, and (b) Suggestions for changes to existing education curricula, through brainstorming sessions.

por.por_cntn:
The US / Morocco Workshop on Sensors and Wireless Network for Smart Cities was organized on January 5-7, 2016 in Rabat, Morocco. The workshop aims to foster collaboration between the US and Morocco in the area of future smart cities, specifically with regard to research needs in sensors and wireless networking and computing that will enable smart cities. 

The challenges that motivated us to pursue this initiative is that developing smart cities is a global challenge and therefore needs global perspectives. It is worthwhile bringing scholars from different countries together to discuss challenges in smart city development, brainstorm possible approaches, and share experiences. Recent technical achievements in sensors and controls integrated with active systems can contribute to the ability to manage our built environment and tailor it to our preferences, while still achieving optimal operation, energy conservation, sustainability and resiliency. A smart city behaves as a Cyber-Physical System (CPS) that deeply integrates sensing, computation, communication, and control. The workshop included concept papers presented by US and Moroccan researchers. Discussions in breakout sessions and brainstorming sessions. The workshop also developed a list of recommendation of challenges of application of sensors and wireless networks in smart cities.

Recommendations

Four parallel breakout sessions were organized. The purpose of the breakout sessions was to brainstorm on different challenges and come up with recommendations of mutual interest between the US and Morocco. The sessions noted the active participation of students and researchers from Morocco. They had stimulating and interesting session discussions. The following are the list of technical challenges that were developed: 

Enabling Technologies:

-       Develop technologies that strike the balance between low cost and reliable IoT devices. 

-       Heterogeneity of different sensors will present a challenge on how to integrat,  fuse the data, and to learn from it.

-       As the number of devices will increase in smart city applications and given the limited bandwidth in wireless networks, there is a challenge on how to ensure high performance spectrum efficiency with required QoS. 

-       There is a need on address how to develop cloud computing, high performance computing for the big data generated by smart cities. 

-       How these technologies can be compliant with organizations and planners of smart cities.

Smart transportation Systems:

-       Networking issues in connected vehicles: in particular vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) & vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communications, simulations platforms, vehicle-to-devices (V2D) communications to enhance security for pedestrian using smart phones or other devices users carry to have mutual warning system.

-       Security issues in connected vehicles: in particular issue that involve intra-vehicles communications will open the door for more security challenges.

-       Possibility of exploring developing incentives to affect people behavior in how they will utilize public transportation.

-       Data access and data sharing: there is a need to explain to people the importance of sharing the data and how to make it available to scientists.

-       We’re entering the big data era and data deluge, we need not only need to distill data but also to take in consideration the importance of the data we’re collecting, the scarcity, and the context of the analytics.

-       Data integrity and privacy: no matter what you do data will be noisy. There is a need for robust analytics to handle uncertainty.

Water system:

-       Sustainable agriculture: in Morocco there is problem with water availability.  Morocco is a great agriculture nation but there is a lack of water. There is a need for optimized irrigation system. 

-       Mapping water quality nationwide around morocco: rivers are not as good as they are represented we can use satellite and geographical system to develop accurate mapping of rivers.

-       Increase food quality and quantity food supply in particular fish and aquaculture. There is a need for fish farms and there is a need for sensor and sensor network including sensing for bacteria heavy metals and how to make them cheap.

Smart building:

-      There is a need to collect and archive information about residential and commercial building data. This collected data will drive research agenda.

-       Infrastructure development: building energy management system

-       Development of sensing devices for smart building applications

-       Development of control devices for smart building applications

-       Development of microgrids within the scope of smart building applications

-       Open data is not available: there is a need to collect data and characterize the environment.

Education and Partnership models:

Models for partnership between Morocco and the US: For the Ph.D. program in Morocco, there is no formal courses that are given to graduate student. This gap can be filled with visits from the US. Where scholars can come and give seminars. Student exchange program and how it can be funded. Fulbright can be used to provide support but it is limited. Other foundation can be explored to provide support as well.
